description: Sum of totient functions over arguments running through reduced residue system of n.
comments: Phi-summation results over numbers not exceeding n are given in A002088 while summation over divisor-set of n would give n. This is a further way of Phi-summation.Equals row sums of triangle A143620 [_Gary W. Adamson_, Aug 27 2008]
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..1000
example: Given n = 36, its reduced residue system is {1, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23, 25, 29, 31, 35}; the Euler phi of these terms are {1, 4, 6, 10, 12, 16, 18, 22, 20, 28, 30, 24}. Summation over this last set gives 191. So a(36) = 191.
mathematica: Join[{1}, Table[Sum[EulerPhi[i] * KroneckerDelta[GCD[i, n], 1], {i, n - 1}], {n, 2, 60}]] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Nov 02 2014 *)
author: _Labos Elemer_, Jan 17 2000
